alert.note: Alert for Appanoose; Black Hawk; Bremer; Butler; Davis; Grundy; Jasper; Mahaska; Marion; Marshall; Monroe; Poweshiek; Tama; Wapello (Iowa) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Wind Chill Warning issued January 13 at 11:48AM CST until January 16 at 12:00PM CST by NWS DesMoines
info.description: ...Blizzard Conditions Continue Today... ...Life Threatening Wind Chills later today and into Early Next Week... .An area of light snow is moving across central Iowa today. In addition, northwest winds will again increase with a few gusts to 40 mph possible. The new snow will become blowing snow and help keep near whiteout conditions at times, especially in rural areas. Significant drifting is also likely. These stronger winds are ushering in Arctic cold air with current temperatures already falling below zero over western Iowa. This Arctic air combined with breezy to strong winds will create dangerous temperatures and wind chills through early next week, with wind chill values down to 45 below zero expected. ...WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 PM CST THIS EVENING... ...WIND CHILL WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 6 PM THIS EVENING TO NOON CST TUESDAY... * WHAT...For the Winter Weather Advisory, snow. Additional snow accumulations of up to one inch. For the Wind Chill Warning, dangerously cold wind chills expected. Wind chills as low as 40 below zero. * WHERE...Portions of Central Iowa east of Interstate 35. * WHEN...For the Winter Weather Advisory, until 6 PM CST this evening. For the Wind Chill Warning, from 6 PM this evening to noon CST Tuesday. * IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions. Blowing snow will significantly reduce visibility. The dangerously cold wind chills could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 10 minutes.
info.instruction: Slow down and use caution while traveling. Avoid outside activities if possible. When outside, make sure you wear appropriate clothing, a hat, and gloves. For the latest travel conditions, check the Iowa 511 app, www.511ia.org, or dial 511.
